Slavery in ancient Rome describes the system well. The main original source of enslavement was capture in war. But the modern form of slavery in the Americas with people of African ancestry was a racialized form of slavery. That is, an ideology was spun out to justify the enslavement as a permanent condition due to the alleged biological inferiority of the people who were enslaved. Europeans were probably never subjected to a racialized form of slavery like this. At least, none of the answers point to any. However, that said, the form of racialized lifetime slavery as an inherited condition for people of African ancestry in North America did evolve out of an earlier non-racialized form of slavery used by the English colonizers in North America. That happened because a peculiar feature of British colonization in North America was the use of large numbers of European slaves. The percentage of Europeans brought to North America as slaves (bond-servants) varied, from maybe 20 percent in New England to 80 percent in Virginia (the latter estimate from historian Philip Foner). Their circumstances of life after they were freed were also not especially rosy. According to one study (mentioned by historian Gary Nash), about 80 percent spent the rest of their lives as tenant farmers, hired farm laborers, or drunks and vagabonds. Due to the enclosures in England, where the entrepreneurial landowners and farmers were kicking peasants off their traditional lands and denying them their traditional feudal rights, by the 1500s and 1600s there were huge numbers of unemployed people tramping the roads in England. In about 1550 leaders of parliament first suggested enslaving them as lifetime slaves. This was opposed as too extreme to get political support. But in 1597 a Vagrancy Act was passed that did allow the authorities to round up any unemployed person, and put them into a forced labor regime for specified period of servitude. They were often branded with an “S” or “V”. In the early 1600s with the founding of the English colonies in North America these people were being shipped to North America and sold to plantation owners. They were called “bond servants” — bound in service to a master. They were chattel slaves. They could be sold. They were not paid wages. They could be whipped. Females were often raped. But the laws required they be set free after seven years of enslavement. So it was not a lifetime, inherited condition. The first Africans that came to North American in 1619 were simply integrated into this system. Not treated differently. That’s because slavery at that time was not yet racialized or based on skin color. That didn’t happen til the early 1700s. Due to various revolts in which the African and European slaves cooperated, the plantation class decided on a divide and conquer strategy of creating a worse condition for the African slaves, and they started a campaign of racialized disparagement of them due to allegedly being an uncivilized group. They then made their condition life time and inherited. This was also highly profitable for the landowners because they could buy a lifetime slave for the same price as a European bond-servant (who they had to free after seven years). And they would have their children for free. The systems of racialized forms of enslavement in the Americas grew out of European conquest, and were part of a strategy of dividing up the various groups of the subordinate population, and increasing their profits from the venture. But it’s not possible to understand how the later system of racialized slavery came into existence without keeping in mind the older non-racial form of slavery it grew out of.

Domestication of animals took time... Slaves were not of your family, clan, tribe, city, or ethnic/language group - however that was defined at the time. Sometimes men would bring home wives from another culture (especially traders, as I'm going to assume that this was the oldest way of getting someone who knew the language & culture of the group that might be a potential trade partner and keeping those relationships cordial - since the trading houses would have literally traded children to marry into each other's families). Sometimes a traveling trader or even a raider might stick around and settle down with a "local girl" - depending again on the time & place. The early Germanic tribes, early British peoples, the people who would become the French, and so forth would have been enslaving each other - the Egyptians enslaved black and the various Semitic peoples who were their neighbors, the Romans enslaved the Greeks, the Greeks enslaved each other, and so forth & so on until transportation & trade for centuries before it got to the point where African tribes could capture neighbors and sell them to Arab slave traders who would take them to various ports to ship to places like Ancient Rome and more recently (say for the last four out of five centuries) Europe and then the Western Hemisphere. Slaves were the forerunners of machinery - since there were no machines and someone had to keep animals on task when muscle power or running water (grist mills for grinding grain into flour) were the only options for getting a task done - since no steam power, no electricity, and certainly no internal combustion engines - then someone had to be assigned that job. Children or slaves might be the ones set to watching animals, doing farm labor, spinning wool or linen, and any of the other host of tasks that have now been relegated to paid employees - many of them using machinery of some kind. This was a very different world back then - nothing could be automated because they hadn't invented the tools to develop the tools to build anything that would work that way.

If they ran away, they were searched out by the government, returned to the owner and branded. Outright slavery, which in practice was no different than serfdom, was outlawed in Russia in 1723, when Peter the Great, converted household slaves into serfs. The difference between the statuses was in legal paperwork only. Not only did serfdom flourish in Russia among nobles, government and the church were large beneficiaries of it as well. The official estimate is that 10.5 million Russians were privately owned, 9.5 million were in state ownership and another 900,000 serfs were under the Tsar's patronage (udelnye krestiane) before the Great Emancipation of 1861. One of the most famous works of Russian literature is called “Dead souls” it specifically refers to the practice of selling and buying people, the machinations around it and the lives of parasitic nobles, who benefited from it.  One interesting practice and in fact a law that existed around 15th century was called “Yur’ev Day” or “St. George’s Day” . At the end of the fall harvest there were two weeks when all serfs had an opportunity to change their owners. They could take their families and possessions and move to either another landowner who had a reputation of being more fair or leave for freer parts of Russia that didn’t have serfdom - in the North, Ural or Siberia. However the practice was ended by Boris Godunov, as many nobles didn’t like it. To this day there is a saying in Russian “So much for Yur’ev Day, babushka” - it refers to broken promises.
